posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

I've said a few times I used to have a paper that talked about this in more depth and like the agricultural carrying capacity of the valley at the time of Spanish contact, but I lost it and haven't been able to relocate it.

I DID recently find the paper "Settlement Pattern and Chinampa Agriculture at Tenochtitlan" by Edward E. Calnek, which is interesting, because it basically goes against the prevailing information you'll find online and even in seemingly reputable sources about Chinampas:

- The paper makes a distinction between the staked out land plots in the city, and the actual agricultural chinampa farms (which were thinner strips next to them, and occupied less space

- It comes to the conclusion that Chinampas weren't actually that agriculturally productive and wouldn't have been used to even sustain a quarter of a family's dietary intake in most cases (though some parts of Tenochtitlan and specific residences (which actually don't seem to be as small and consistently single-roomed as people seem to think/often assume) had proportionally larger or smaller chinampas), and were instead likely used for supplementary fresh herbs and vegetables

Among some other stuff I forgot about. It also references a large dataset the author has access to of maps and land survey information that helps reconstruct floorplans of residences and land plots in Tenochtitlan based on colonial period records and modern construction in Mexico City, and for obvious reasons I am quite interested in that data, but the paper is from the 70s and I suspect tho can't confirm the author is deceased.

1/2

>>14595729
>All that "Catholic Church" really means is the universal embodiment of Christ's Body of followers.

From the beginning the Catholic Church has had a hierarchical, episcopal, visible structure, as testified in the 100s by St. Ignatius of Antioch and St. Irenaeus.

By the year 180, apostolic succession was understood as the sure indicator of orthodoxy. Thus St Irenaeus of Lyons, writing against the Gnostics in that year:
>Since, however, it would be very tedious, in such a volume as this, to reckon up the successions of all the Churches, we do put to confusion all those who... whether by an evil self-pleasing, by vainglory, or by blindness and perverse opinion, assemble in unauthorized meetings; [we do this, I say,] by indicating that tradition derived from the apostles, of the very great, the very ancient, and universally known Church founded and organized AT ROME by the two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul; as also [by pointing out] the faith preached to men, which comes down to our time by means of the successions of the bishops.

>For it is A MATTER OF NECESSITY that EVERY CHURCH SHOULD AGREE WITH THIS CHURCH [i.e. Rome], on account of its preeminent authority.
-St Irenaeus, Against Heresies 3.3.2, 180 AD (emphasis added)

But, it may be added, if we wish to locate the Church founded by Jesus, we need to locate the one that has the four chief marks or qualities of his Church, as set forth in the Nicene Creed. St. Irenaeus emphasized only one of these: that the Church must be apostolic.

But the true Church is also: One, Holy, and Catholic, in addition to being apostolic. And the Catholic Church is the only Church which possesses those four marks. By contrast, the Eastern Orthodox churches are neither one nor Catholic, being primarily ethnic churches.

Hebrews 1 is the beginning of an apologetic for the Christian faith against the Jewish religion, to which the original audience was being called back. The apostle wastes no time in this epistle as it is not only anonymous but contains no greeting at all, going straight into the argument. To begin his defense of Christ the apostle shows how superior Jesus is even to the angels. The underlying context then is the intention to show Jesus to be inferior to nothing, to show how to go back would be to go back to nothing, since they would be leaving everything.

In verse 10 the apostle quotes from Psalm 102 prefaced with the words "To the Son He says". Now that God said this does not mean in the narrative God is the "character" speaking like He is when He says to Moses "I am the God of Abraham", but God "spoke" the Psalm since it is scripture and all scripture is God-breathed. In saying that the words of the Psalm are said "To the Son" the author identifies the Son as the one to whom the psalmist is speaking, not that the Son is like what is written there or that it could be applied to Him but that it is about Him.

In choosing the text they believed to be closest to the original manuscript of the book of Hebrews, the UBS committee looked at the very oldest and best manuscripts still in existence today. Several methods helped them decide what is probably the original wording. One, of course, is how many of the very oldest and best manuscripts agree.


Another method is to determine which of the variations were most likely to have been changed by later copyists. For instance, when a NT writer is referring to an OT quotation, he often has it worded slightly differently from the exact quote in the Septuagint (Paul is especially noted for this).


So, if one NT manuscript has an OT scripture quoted exactly as it appears in the Septuagint, and another has a slightly different wording, the manuscript that differs slightly is more likely to have the proper, original wording. (Later copyists strongly tended to “correct” the original NT manuscripts by making their OT quotes conform exactly to the wording in the Septuagint version.)


Another consideration is that later Church copyists would often change the wording of a scripture if it seemed to contradict a teaching of the Roman Church.[1] Therefore, if the wording of an ancient manuscript seems to contradict a later teaching of the Roman Church, it is more likely to have the original wording than another ancient manuscript which (at the same verse) seems to agree with that Church teaching.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Incredibly long timeframes. That's what people who don't believe in evolution fail to grasp. They deny that these big sweeping changes could happen, and they're right. It's small, gradual changes over an incredibly long period of time that makes one species into another. Imagine the animal that became whales. They lived close to the coast and ate fish. Those that had broader flatter limbs could more easily swim around and catch fish and escape predators. Over time, those with broad flat limbs didn't get eaten or starve at a better rate than those without to the point that those without broad flat limbs just stopped existing, and we get a proto whale. This happens over an incomprehensibly long time frame. If you really consider how long evolution has had to play around with these tiny changes, you start to see how many tiny changes have been made, and they add up. And because only those changes that are beneficial take over as compared to something like a birth defect or big mutation you have millions or billions of small changes made over millions or billions of generations all heading in a vaguely similar direction until the environment changes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14598597
So retroviruses can transcribe their RNA into the host's DNA, but it's usually constrained to one cell. However, if the retrovirus infects a cell that creates sperm or eggs, every single cell of the host's children will have the virus in its DNA. This is called an endogenous retrovirus or ERV. It is passed onto all future progeny by its carriers.
Each individual ERV inserts into a random place in the genome and there's around 3 billion possible insertion sites. Humans have almost 100.000 ERVs and all but a couple hundred are shared with chimps, both when it comes to type and location. The further we are from another animal on what we think is the evolutionary tree of life, the fewer ERVs we share.
That's one very small part of the evidence via ERVs. I can continue if you want :)

>>14598991
Humans make vitamin D when UV from the sun hits their skin. At the equator, UV from the sun is very intense. Skin needs something that can absorb it to make sure it doesn't do a lot of damage. That's melanin. At higher latitudes, UV is much weaker. Not as much melanin is needed to protect the skin and too much melanin would prevent adequate synthesis of vitamin D, leading to weak bones, etc. Over generations, paler skin is selected and the amount of melanin decreases.

The eye thing seems random.

>>14593228
Life was hard for peasants. They owed a certain amount of work to their lord in return for the right to grow crops and raise animals for themselves. This work tax is w here the nonsense about only working a third of the year comes from. The average peasant did not have money, everything was paid for in kind. This makes it very hard to calculate their wealth, but during the early period it was not easy to get your hands on anything not made locally.
A peasant's dwelling was a large single room which would be shared with their entire family and their animals during the winter. Beds were made of straw. They were generally illiterate. The village priest was also drawn from the lower classes and often had a poor understanding of Latin and theology compared to more noble born priests and bishops. A peasant could not leave the manor without permission from their lord. While under some forms of serfdom a lord could force you to fight, especially as time went on, this burden fell on freemen and later professional mercenaries. On the other hand it was not unheard of for villages to suffer raids from knights without wars to fight. Hunting was for nobles, a peasant could get in big trouble if they were caught hunting. Fishing however was OK. Most meat peasants ate was preserved. They did get some meat and fish but the vast majority of their diet was grain based. People didn't live much shorter lives than now, through many children died young, and women died in childbirth at much higher rates. Only members of the nobility would be as tall as people today, almost everyone was short by today's standards.

Yall really should use the term serf and not peasant. Peasant is a farmer. A farmer can be a bound to the land, or a free renter, or a free landowner, or even a member of the gentry could call himself a farmer if he works closely with the production of his land even on a managerial level of other farmers on his land. Being a farmer is not a bad thing. Oliver Cromwell would have called himself a farmer for an example, although the period is wrong it gives you an idea of the meaning of a farmer into the early modern period. Also when we are talking about "peasants" where in Europe are we talking makes a big difference in terms of class. A "peasant" in England is different from one in a French kingdom who is different from a central European kingdom and so on. Also you have to consider regions where farming was poor. Many Scots and Irish "peasants" would not have "farming" skills but pastoral skills with livestock.

>>14591064
Greek helmet, 7th century bc, Crete


These helmets and the three mitrai exhibited below them are the finest pieces of a large cache of armor that came to light in southern central Crete, where it was undoubtedly made. The inscriptions suggest that the armor was captured as booty and offered as a dedication. In repoussé on both sides of one helmet is a pair of winged youths grasping a pair of intertwined snakes. Below them are two panthers with a common head. The helmet is inscribed "Neopolis." In repoussé on both sides of the other helmet is a horse; incised on each cheekpiece is a lion. The inscription states that Synenitos, the son of Euklotas, took this object.

>>14592909
Bronze helmet of the 5th century BC found on the Taman Peninsula, Russia. Photo source: Institute of Archaeology of the Russian Academy of Sciences
A Corinthian helmet was discovered in a 5th century BC grave in the Taman Peninsula, southwest Russia, according to RIA Novosti news agency.Made of bronze, Corinthian helmets covered the entire head and neck, with slits for the eyes and mouth, protruding cheek covers (paragnathides in Greek) as well as a curved protrusion in the back to protect the nape of the neck.The helmet has a padded interior made of fabric or leather to protect the warrior’s skull. These helmets were indispensable for the Greek hoplites, the famous foot soldiers of the phalanxes, as they were highly protective because they completely covered the headOften their crest was surmounted by a crest (lophos) with a horsehair plume. The one found is corroded and highly fragmented, but its discovery is extremely significant for historical purposes. The Corinthian helmet is the only one of its kind discovered north of the Black Sea.

Kingdoms, principalities, etc. were more personal, focused largely on the relationship of the ruler to their noble landowners and the personage of the ruler as being one and the same with the state. A state is more impersonal and professionally bureaucratic. The ruler (or executive) has less direct influence and thus must work with the legislative body and the state exists beyond any one ruler. The nation which may have existed in some vague, incoherent form but was organized into a thing after the French Revolution and Napoleonic Wars destroyed the idea of the divine right of kings. Legitimacy and authority had to come from somewhere and people needed to fight for something so liberals took these vague notions and gave them a more coherent, concrete form in the idea of the nation. Legitimacy came not top down from God but rather bottom up from the people. The king may be dead but the nation yet lives. The people are the nation and the state is their representative.

That was where nationalism as a political force came from and why it's an invention of the late 18th/early 19th century.

>>14592607
Classic "nationalism" (built on the city-state) existed a long time ago. Like Rome and Greece, each state was rather small, had privileged citizens who had say in politics and constituted the majority in the army, contrary to slaves, servants, barbarians, etc. In that circumstance, nationalism for the "citizens" existed and thrived.

As for modern nationalism, it emerged in late 18th century as a popular and revolutionary movement marked by a communal identification with one’s nation (i.e. "the Irish" or "the Turks"), and while they often looked back on ancient history to draw inspiration, they included things like now-modern political campaigns to raise awareness and mobilize people and establish the modern nation-state.

Hobsbawm defines nationalism as the ideology that the political and national units should coincide.

(1) He views the nation as a changing, evolving, modern construct that is brought into being by nationalism, and not the other way around.

(2) He agrees that there are certain political, technical, administrative and economic conditions necessary for the emergence of the nation, such as the existence of administrative and educational infrastructure.

(3) Finally, Hobsbawm believes nationalism is constructed from above, although it needs to be studied from bellow as this is where it takes root and is most powerful and volatile.

I think there is some confusion that english speakers encounter about the notion of "ethnic" in the classical greek world. The word "Ethnos" is litterally a ethnic group, you might say this is a "race' , but that still doesn't cut it. Greeks used ethnos to signify basically a tribal group of people. However because Greeks spoke different dialects of Greek, and because they were never unified politically and defined their differences in what political systems they used there was never a Greek nation in the ethno-political sense nor exactly in the precice cultural sense. Rather the interesting thing with Greeks is that although they had no uniform national-ethnic identity , they certainly used a term as an exonym to define anyone who was not Greek, that is the "barbarian". Thus this exonym was the defining factor, rather than defining the characteristics of a "Greek race", since this would devolve into too many confusions. For example Plato says that the "ideal" Republic would be a unified "Greek state", but that is mainly to protect the Greeks from being enslaved by barbarians. Thus the classical Greeks intellectuals did not recognize the inborn state of nationhood and polities of barbarians as some kind of natural political entity (like John Locke would argue), but as theologically opposed to them. This was not so different in how the Jews defined themselves against the "idolatrus" non-Jews.

https://digressionsnimpressions.typepad.com/digressionsimpressions/2018/09/on-socratess-ethno-nationalist-political-theology.html

You want living knowledge rather than rote memorization. Construct a narrative, or a mental model of what happened and why, with specific information flowing in to support and refine the model.
Like, if it's WWI, what are the dynamics that lead to the war and its progression? What about the war was contingent and what was determined? Then, like math, you work the problem by inserting and evaluating specifics. It's the act of doing things with the data that makes it stick.

This sort of thing happens more often than you'd expect.

A conquering force comes into a nation and brings with it a higher level of civilisation, science, techonolgy, etc.
For a while the native population benefits from these things and begin cultivating newer crops and animals, begin building with more advanced metals, begin speaking a more sophisticated language.
But eventually the conquering force has to leave to tend to matters elsewhere and the native population revert to their primitive ways.

You could show them iron, where to mine it, how to refine it and form it into useful tools and weapons. But within a generation they will revert back to Bronze, a weaker and harder to acquire metal.
Civilisation takes many many generations to develop. It's a culture, not a state

posts.com:
David Pearce's arguments for non-materialist physicalism:

https://www.physicalism.com/

>Natural science promises a complete story of the universe. No "element of reality" should be missing from the mathematical formalism of physics, i.e. relativistic quantum field theory or its more speculative extension, M-theory. On pain of magic, every gross property of the natural world must be theoretically reducible to fundamental physics. The Standard Model in physics is experimentally well tested. Within its conceptual framework, consciousness would seem not only causally impotent but physically impossible. Hence the "explanatory gap" and the Hard Problem of consciousness.

>In recent years, a minority of researchers have proposed that the Hard Problem is an artifact of materialist metaphysics. Contra Kant, but following Schopenhauer, Bertrand Russell, Grover Maxwell, Michael Lockwood, Galen Strawson, et al., the new idealists conjecture that the phenomenology of one's mind reveals the intrinsic nature of the physical – the elusive "fire" in the equations about which physics is silent. Mathematical physics yields an exhaustive description of the relational-structural properties of the world. This description may ultimately be encoded by the universal wavefunction of post-Everetta quantum mechanics: our best mathematical description of reality. However, our presupposition that the intrinsic character of the physical lacks phenomenal properties is an additional metaphysical assumption. The assumption is hugely plausible, but it's not a scientific discovery. Perhaps most tellingly, the only part of the "fire" in the equations to which one ever enjoys direct access, i.e. one's own consciousness, discloses phenomenal properties that are inconsistent with a materialist ontology. For reasons unexplained, the natural world contains first-person facts. The world supports at least one non-zombie. And natural science gives no reason to believe that one is special.

What does it mean to be material? What is a material state as compared to a non-material state?
>I just don't see how this is problematic.
I don't think the problem is that consciousness is private while matter is not. The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy explains it well:
>"In more detail, the challenge arises because it does not seem that the qualitative and subjective aspects of conscious experience—how consciousness “feels” and the fact that it is directly “for me”—fit into a physicalist ontology, one consisting of just the basic elements of physics plus structural, dynamical, and functional combinations of those basic elements. It appears that even a complete specification of a creature in physical terms leaves unanswered the question of whether or not the creature is conscious. And it seems that we can easily conceive of creatures just like us physically and functionally that nonetheless lack consciousness. This indicates that a physical explanation of consciousness is fundamentally incomplete: it leaves out what it is like to be the subject, for the subject."
https://iep.utm.edu/hard-problem-of-conciousness/

If the world is entirely quantitative and objective, it seems contradictory to say such a world also includes subjective and qualitative phenomenon like consciousness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Japanese martial arts became practiced as popular sports. Competition drives development of a martial art. Judo and BJJ both developed from Jujutsu, and are both sports train realistically and compete regularly with a large pool of competitors. And kickboxing grew from karate in Japan and America (in the early years of American kickboxing, it was also called full-contact karate). Chinese martial arts for a long time didn't compete regularly or train realistically (not even including sparring always). You can see even with Japanese styles, there are plenty of schools that don't spar or compete, and the lack of realistic training makes them ineffective. You see plenty of BJJ in the UFC, but not much Japanese Jiu-Jitsu or Aikido. Plenty of karate schools teaching unrealistically too.

Some forms of Chinese martial arts like Shuai jiao (wrestling) held up better, but Chinese striking arts lagged behind. Things have gotten better in China since the introduction of Sanda competitions around 1979. Here's a video giving some background from the first Sanda National Team head coach and one of the first Sanda fighters. He sums up some of the issues they had when starting out and what they took from.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NDOkPNzKGBg

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14601361
Both were developed as practical fighting methods for the battlefield. Japanese jiujutsu aims to defeat and kill an opponent in armor. However, after a long period of peace, jiujutsu became a competition to subdue, not kill, the opponent. On the other hand, Chinese martial arts developed not as a competition but as a self-discipline and show, more like a dance. Judo is a type of jiujutsu that became a competition in this way, but it was adopted by police forces in many countries because its ability to subdue without killing the opponent made it suitable for the use of force by law enforcement agencies.

>>14592198
>How does a immaterial thing interact with a material thing while still being immaterial?
It doesn't interact, one (awareness) simply casts the other as an appearance by its natural power while itself remaining immutable and unconditioned, this is not an interaction by definition which is reciprocal and which involves both parties being changed or impacted. Since this is totally non-reciprocal, it's not an interaction. In the Hindu schools of Advaita Vedanta and Samkhya, the mind and intellect are made out of the subtle elements (tanmatras) which are capable of interacting causally with the physical world, experience takes place when this intellect and its workings receive or are bathed in the light of Brahman's awareness which itself stays unchanged. Because the mind is able to interact casually with the world while being illuminated by Brahman's awareness, this provides an explanation of how the mind can change and be changed by the world despite consciousness (awareness) being non-physical.

>It is perhaps worth noting at this point that the Sāṅkhya-Yoga (and Advaita Vedanta) view thereby avoids one of the most serious pitfalls of Cartesian dualism, since on the Indian account, mental causation does not violate any physical conservation laws. By including mind in the real of matter, mental events are granted causal efficacy, and are thereby able to directly initiate bodily motions. And, conversely, material objects are able to have genuine mental effects, as required by normal accounts of, say, the flow of information involved in perceptual awareness of the environment. The representational content of sensory experiences, such as those which attend perceiving the blueness of the sky or the pungent flavor of espresso, can now be treated as straightforward consequences of the physical environment's causal impingements upon the mind.
https://www.pure.ed.ac.uk/ws/portalfiles/portal/28892783/Schweizer_consciousness_and_space_1.pdf

>however the association of Brahmins with prominent wealth is largely a modern phenomenon, traditionally they were much more focused on their religious/priestly duties and engaging in commerce was shunned.
This is one of the few things I actually know a lot about due to my studying of indian inscriptions.

At least where my ancestors are from, Brahmins had almost no political or military power. They did not own land or make rules. They were hired by Shudras (yes the farmer caste) to record things of note and keep genealogical trees. This setup was epitomized in medieval South India where the landed Shudra gentry often formed the warrior class and administered most kingdoms. Yet, it was commonplace in North India as well. Many Rajput records describe a similar situation, though the warrior class was more important than the farmer class.

>Two temple donor records from warrior families of the 14th century claim to be Shudras. One states that Shudras are the bravest, the other states that Shudras are the purest.

So to circle back to your post, I agree that ascetics were usually of "upper caste"

There is nothing substantial or concrete here.

The city was originally built on top of loose sediment and mud. Sanitation problems arising from population growth forced the Spanish to drain it in order to prevent disease and expand the urban networks to accommodate new settlers.

Once they drained the lake, most structures simply sank in on themselves and were easy to demolish at the foundation. Also most of the newer buildings like cathedrals and government buildings were built using the stones from Mesoamericans buildings rather than mining and refining it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14600412
A lot of the city was dismantled during the siege: The Conquistadors, Tlaxcaltecas, Texcocas, etc would slowly breach more and more of the city (often being driven back and then retaking stuff), and would break buildings and fill in canals and stuff as they went to avoid dense urban combat

Obviously, that didn't impact the entire city instantly, but even within a few years after the siege, a lot of buildings would have been demolished and rebuilt (even using the same stones, as others have said, you can still see some Aztec sculptures and reliefs on some historic spanish buildings) even if not all of them were and the city retained more of it's original layout. From there it was a more gradual process

>>14601245
The city is the whole "island" seen there, but as you can tell there's a grid of canals running through much of it, it's actually mostly a network of artificial islands radiating out from a few original natural ones, which you can see are the solid green areas without the canal networks running through those bits

A lot of the green would be farmland, but it was freeily mixed in with residential neighorhoods and sometimes even very urbanized areas (which also had large botanical gardens and the like): The artifficial islands which most of the city was made out of was also a technique used to make basically hydroponic farmland irrigated by the canal network (see . >>14599916 )

It's better to think of it less as "city surrounded by farmland", and more as "Mesoamerican cities had more spread out layouts with dense, urban cores of temples and plazas and the like, and then radial suburbs of agricultural land and commoner residences around that" because that's the broader trend with Mesoamerican city planning. If anything Tenochtitlan is more constrained then a lot of other really big Mesoamerican cities which, due to not being on the water, could have suburbs covering dozens (or even hundreds in really extreme cases, pic) of square kilometers

1/2

It's not propoganda, it's literally a colonial decree passed in 1725 (thought it was earlier then that but that's the date cursory googling gives me) in any case other drops in sanitation standards are documented in other respects much earlier then that. >people had to marry and have children extremely early to deal with terrible living conditions causing high mortality

I've heard contradictory information on marriage ages with the Mexica, so I'm not gonna try to argue that. But I've read multiple papers on mortality rates and life expectancy in the few studies that exist on it are pretty comparable to (like at Teotihuacan) or slightly above Europe at the time. The Teotihuacan one is "An Estimate of Mortality in a Pre-Columbian
Urban Population", where to quote the abstract: "Comparison with other populations revealed basic similarities in mortality between Teotihuacan and Old World preindustrial cities". In the interest of honesty, it should be noted tho that it infers from the data that despite Teotihuacan's plumbing systems, it probably had similar sanitation issues as Old World cities. (though the paper also isn't a comprehensive deep dive on the city's sanitation, and there's also 1000 years between the Teotihuacanos and Aztec, and Aztec sanitation practices being pretty high is pretty widely established in written records)

Also, if you look at Smith's work he details in "At Home with the Aztecs", at towns where we have archaeological records of both the Aztec and Spanish imperial periods, there's a much, much greater impact on both general day to day life, city planning, and reductions to life expectancy during Spanish conquests/control periods then when the Aztec took over those areas.

>The ethnohistorian Ortiz de Montellano puts life expectancy at birth for the Aztec at 37 years, but the cited source does not, in fact, support this figure. A decidedly somber picture emerges when we examine life expectancies at older ages (see Table 1). >>14593542

Brutalism as an artistic movement was literally just a bunch of edgy retards who thought that since old buildings - representative of obsolete, bourgeois thinking - were aesthetically pleasing and had all sorts of embellishments, progressive ideologies should embrace designs that were stark and featureless. It was genuinely that fucking stupid. Concrete was also just becoming feasible for large-scale building projects, so because it was the new thing everybody wanted to build with it. Same reason the '80s had a lot of shit electronics in music. 'We have this shiny new toy so we're going to use it just because we can, without stopping to think about whether it actually improves anything.'

So it was just novelty for novelty's sake, with a dash of socialist contrarianism thrown in.

It was the carpet bombing of Europe during WW2 that led to brutalism actually becoming popular. Obviously, postwar Europe had a lot of rebuilding to do and not a lot of money to do it with. Brutalist buildings were cheap, which kickstarted the first wave.

Now, think about an architect's career progression: what is the number one thing that will give an architect influence over their field?

Actually getting their buildings built, of course.

Because institutions were forced to turn to Brutalist architects due budgetary constraints, a bunch of otherwise talentless hacks were propelled to the top of their profession and were able to open their own agencies and give lectures at universities and generally pretend that they were artistic geniuses rather than just the cheapest option available. But at the end of the day, they were the ones who actually got their buildings built, so critics, academics, and other architects went along with it, because what is rule no. 1 of being an artist? Everyone will make excuses for you if you're successful.

Once the Brutalists were in, they naturally used their money and influence make sure the whole field was dominated by like-minded people.

We know Paul is right here because Abraham was seen as righteous in the eyes of God prior to circumcision, or the laws given to Moses, just like the righteous of old such as Noah and Enoch, etc. The Law in its spiritual sense is still binding. Read the Epistle of Barnabas to show how there are legitimate spiritual principles behind the letter of the law that reveal its true spirit. Paul doesn’t preach antinomianism, he actually applies the Torah even stricter, as Jesus does in Matthew 5-7. He is repeating what Jews such as Hillel were saying, that the entirety of the law is founded on loving your neighbor as yourself, which Christ taught too.

Gassing has a shitton of advantages:
1) cheap
2) make use of material you already have (delousing agent)
3) clandestine (from guards, citizens, and prisoners alike)
4) conserves war material during the height of shortages
5) much less messy
6) allows convenient and voluntary stripping of all possessions beforehand so they can be sold off
The PTSD stuff is a meme. The Nazis didn't really get the idea of PTSD the way we do today. Certainly the SS didn't. I mean even the Allies didn't get PTSD at the time; Patton famously beat a shell-shocked soldier for refusing to go back to the front.
>but why use delousing agent instead of nerve gas like sarin?
delousing agent is cheap, available, already on-site (for lice), not suspicious, and so on. Sarin has an immensely long half-life and is incredibly dangerous. Even modest contact could be lethal to someone, posing a constant health risk to the SS guards.

>>14600708

This is the problem when you imagine ancient population dispersal and genetic admixture to be the same thing as a grand strategy game version of settler-colonialism.
European colonisation of the Americas was unique, totally unique in history, comparable maybe to European colonisation of Australia. These populations had been so isolated from one another - genetically, culturally, economically, technologically - that when they re-encountered, their technological level was so vastly different that one was bound to completely genetically dominate the other one. Hell, they'd been isolated for so long that Europeans could kill Amerindians purely by accident with disease, since their immunological history was so different. And even then, Amerindians genes survive throughout the Americas, peaking in Mexico, Peru, Ecuador.
This wasn't the same in the Upper Paleolithic. The populations of Inner and North Eurasia were in a genetic cline that gathered into clusters based on population density and geography, and their cultural, technological and linguistic differences were similarly clinal. After the Neolithic, certain technologies definitely gave some groups the upper hand for an extended period of time - farming, bronze, horses, chariots - but these things didn't necessarily lead to full population replacement, but instead extensive and ongoing admixture, with certain lineages clustering in certain areas, but with most haplogroups still being carried in most Eurasian populations. A constant process of muttification.

>>14600996

>it literally establishes Europeans have the max

Where does it establish that? For west-of-Urals and European populations, the Nganasan+Srubnaya model requires significant contributions from other sources, depending on which part of Europe we're talking about. Some require pretty extensive Western Hunter-Gatherer contributions, while all of them required both WHG and EEF/LBK. The highest Nganasan ratio in Europe is Saamis (29.0%), who are not generally representative of European genetic makeup.

The Yamnaya/WSH were about 50% ANE (which they had inherited from the ESG, who were 75% ANE). Depending on where you go in Europe, WSH can vary from very little to as much as 50% around Scandinavia and the Baltic. Thus, even in the highest ANE genes in Europe, it most likely won't exceed 25%.

Meanwhile, ANE ancestry in Kets can be estimated, using various f4-ratios, at 27% to 43% (depending on reference populations and datasets), vs. 25–53% in various Native American groups. It seems to be around this area in Nganasan people as well.

So even on their tiptoes, Scandi and Balt Euromutts are as ANE as the least-ANE Kets and Injuns (25%).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14601651

>Would someone who is 80% Swedish and 20% Japanese look more Japanese or more Swedish?

Phenotypes can present in different ways. If someone is 80% Swedish and 20% Japanese, then there must have been some intermarrying between Swedes and Japs a long time beforehand, because that ratio is 4:1, not 3:1. For it to be 4:1, there needs to have been isolated intermarrying between Swedish and Japanese further back in their family tree, and those genes are then split into 80 and 20. So, they've had mixed Euro-Asian ancestors quite far back, and so the Tarim mummies must have been mixed between ANE and East Asian for quite some time, in much the same way every other ANE-descended group was.

>Could you infer what Swedes looked like in a vague way from that individual?

But we already know their genetic input to different populations, why do we necessarily need to know what they look like? I imagine that an 80% Swede and 20% Japanese person would look more Swedish than Japanese, but they would still have some recognisably 'Mongoloid' features. But with Tarim mummies and their ANE heritage, we have no way of knowing what ANEs actually looked like, so we don't know if their 'Mongoloid' traits are from ANEs or East Asians. Where they have Caucasoid traits, we can infer that they came from ANEs, but this doesn't imply that ANEs looked European, since Europeans have ANE traits but also quite a lot of other admixture, implying that the European 'look' is a combination of ancestral components, and not just from ANEs. The same could be argued about Kets, Amerindians, etc. We have no way of knowing which percentages of their genes are determining which phenotypical traits because we're only figuring out their haplogroups and genetic distances from other samples, rather than figuring out which genes that they're carrying code for different physical features.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>>14601743

Different genes code for different phenotypical traits, just because someone is genetically close to me it doesn't mean they are going to look the same as me. This is proven by the fact we as Europeans share a large portion of our ANE DNA with Kets and Native Americans, and we don't really look like them.
Incidentally, out of European populations, ones that have some of the highest ANE admixture, like Saami, don't necessarily have the strongest 'Caucasoid' traits, and can have some Mongoloid traits. It can go both ways.
If ANEs are the great Siberian mammoth hunters that contributed to European DNA and civilisation, surely it would show in their material culture? What does their appearance tell us about their intellectual capacity? It seems to me that they were one of many ancestral Paleolithic genetic groups that contributed to European and Siberian populations, and no single one of these is the 'key' to European civilisation. They existed on a broad Eurasian genetic cline from which different genes passed up and down Eurasia, which is why Europeans share genetics with Native Americans. Whether they had broad cheeks and epicanthic folds or whether they looked more European, what does it tell us? We already know we carry their genes and that those genes are part of what makes us European.

>>14599578
The issue isn't so much technology as it was tactics. All of the kit pieces needed to break the trench deadlock (mostly artillery) existed in 1914. What wasn't there was the modern system of how to have infantry and artillery support each other to clear and hold gains when assaulting fortifications like trench lines. This is a good read on the subject.

https://acoup.blog/2021/09/17/collections-no-mans-land-part-i-the-trench-stalemate/
https://acoup.blog/2021/09/24/collections-no-mans-land-part-ii-breaking-the-stalemate/

I mean, theoretically you could have the institutional knowledge put the pieces together more quickly, maybe even before the war itself started, but as a practical matter, that kind of tactical research happens on the battlefield, and it would be pretty unlikely to emerge in anything but the messes of 1915 and 1916.

>Why couldn’t Britain do a major amphibious landing far from the trench frontlines during an entente attack?
Didn't work out so great at Gallipoli. In general, any adversary with railroads is going to be able to reinforce far more rapidly than you'll be able to with whatever improvised beachhead you've got, so unless you get VERY lucky and advance VERY quickly and seize a port more or less intact, this isn't going to work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14600184
That's not entirely correct. Yes, the trench deadlock was a result of very evenly balanced forces along the Western Front in a way that you didn't really see in say, the Middle-East or the Eastern Front. But technology was part and parcel for why the Western Front was so finely balanced.

It was medicinal and agricultural developments that allowed for massively increased populations throughout the 19th century. It was industrial developments that allowed for the production of not only war materiel that could keep pace with the ballooning population, but increase in size relative to the population and equip them far more heavily than any pre-industrial army could dream of. It was the advent of the railroad that allowed armies to spread out across entire fronts. It was the development of things like machine guns and explosive artillery that meant an end to shock tactics in any meaningful form and forced enormous dispersion of forces. And you also needed the civics to keep up, to have military and civil administrative abilities to direct all this stuff into a functioning war economy.

All of those worked together to create a situation where armies occupied a hell of a lot more space than they used to, and when you had powers as big as Germany and France going at it, they used up all of the available space, meaning that even when they projected forces as hard as they could, they still had backlogs of troops just waiting to get into the fight. THAT is what created the evenly matched forces and ultimately the trench deadlock, and it simply could not have occurred 100 years prior.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14599578
>Why couldn’t Britain do a major amphibious landing far from the trench frontlines during an entente attack?
Amphibious attacks require naval superiority. Because the German High Seas Fleet wasn't willing to commit to decisive battle against the British Home Fleet, most of their fleet were in port and ready to activate at a moment's notice.

If you are massing up ships for an amphibious landing in contested waters, you're going to risk the possibility of losing thousands of men in lightly armored transports, getting mauled by u-boats, mines, and preventing the escort fleet from having maneuverability (because the escort ships have to stay near the transports) in pitched battle. And this is before the first boots hit the beach.

Amphibious landings are limited in what areas can be done. Port cities are too fortified and German ships are probably there. Can't be too close to the front lines because the Germans would just move their artillery into shore batteries and sink ships. German coast is unlikely because High Seas Fleet are in port. Then there's the coordination/planning/risk-reward analysis...

The British tried it at Gallipoli to knock the Ottomans out of the war which, arguably, was an easier attack. The Ottomans were considered to have an inferior army, Royal Navy dominating the seas. The Brits also believed (incorrectly), that the Ottomans were stretched thin at Constantinople. And they got fucked up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14601038
The Turks distinguished themselves initially by two factors, their language, and their faith. In this period of time, when a Christian converted to Islam, they'd be ostracised from the Christian community, and be labelled a Turk, and vice versa.
Eventually, enough converted to Islam, and would then be culturally influenced by this into speaking Turkish more, as Greek became more and more associated with Islam, though its likely both communities were somewhat bilingual for sometime owing to the many interactions. Modern Turkish and Modern Greek both experienced a purge of many loanwords so there's less traces but circa 1800s, it was more obvious.
You've also got to keep in mind, it wasn't entirely the Muslims identifying themselves as Turks, but the Christians identifying all Muslims as Turks. In many languages which existed under Ottoman rule, verbs for 'turning Turk', were synonymous with converting to Islam. We can see even in areas without Turkish settlement, local Muslims were referred to as Turks, as in Crete.
